metadata.title: Data scientists can’t just ignore the dreaded “strategy meeting”. | by Dave Dale | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Data scientists can’t just ignore the dreaded “strategy meeting”.
metadata.description: After last week’s JIRA controversy [1], I thought that a natural next step would be to look at how Apple is killing your productivity, and how real data scientists use Linux … Instead let’s turn to…

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: “Military Strategy Revisited, A Critique of the Lykke Formulation” by Lt. Col. Richard E. Berkebile.
7 Proven Templates for Writing Value Propositions That Work

all_paragraphs: After last week’s JIRA controversy [1], I thought that a natural next step would be to look at how Apple is killing your productivity, and how real data scientists use Linux …
This is a joke. Apple fan-kids — please don’t send me hate-mail on LinkedIn.

Instead let’s turn to something that I’ve been wrestling a bit with recently, “Strategy”. If you’re like me, you probably wince when you hear the word. It conjures up images of gibberish-spouting consultants with great hair and implausibly bronzed skin. Glitzy powerpoint slides are probably involved somewhere, as are long meetings where everyone nods but no-one comes out any the wiser.

Pretty much every data scientist I’ve ever spoken to feels the same way about “strategy”. But this raises the interesting question of: why? What triggers this reaction? And should a data scientist care about this stuff in the first place? Well I want to convince you that, as a data scientist, you should, and there exist tools out there for making the whole thing less painful.

One of the reasons data scientists despise (OK, I’m generalising here) “strategic thinking” is that it seems so woolly. However it shouldn’t. The roots of strategic thinking lie with the military — think 19th century Prussians with impressive moustaches, moving wooden soldiers around a map [2]. As data scientists we love a good definition, and there exist perfectly good working definitions of strategy.

Now this is a data science blog, not an organisational culture blog, so I’m going to have to gloss over the interesting way that strategic thinking spread out of the military and into the world of work. But for our purposes, I’m going with a definition of strategy that riffs on the one used by the US military [3]. Unsurprisingly, those guys have thought about this a lot.
Strategy is how an organisation achieves its purpose, by completing its goals, through the deployment of its resources.

You can see why the military go for this kind of thinking — what do we mean by winning, what do we have to do to win, and what tools do we have to do those things. However if you’re not a fan of military metaphors, it also closely parallels Simon Sinek and his “First the why, then the what, then the how” [4].
Put like this, it seems unarguable that any organisation should have some sort of strategy. And yet, somehow, we still end up staggering out of strategy meetings exhausted and unenlightened.

Having sat through many, many hours of data strategy meetings, I feel your pain. However there are two reasons why it’s difficult to maintain that position, one cynical / realistic, the other perhaps more interesting.

The realist’s position is that if you don’t help define the strategy, someone else will do it for you. And do you really want someone else to define the purpose of you and your team, the goals you’ll be measured against and the resources you have? OK, maybe not all organisations involve gladiatorial battles for budget, but you still need to raise your voice in those discussions. Otherwise those shifty so-and-so’s in data engineering will dump a whole load of extra responsibilities on you, without giving you anyone extra to fulfil them.
I jest. I love my colleagues in data engineering. But you get the point — someone, somewhere will be trying to make you do a whole lot of extra work, without paying for it.
There is, however, another less cynical and more interesting reason to care about strategy. If you’ll permit me a bit of “terminologising”, in the above definition, strategy is a fractal concept.

As you zoom into smaller levels of an organisation, you see that the structure of the whole, i.e. the why, the what and the how, is repeated all the way down [5]. In this view, the “why” of one level of the organisation is to fulfil the “what” of the level above it.
Now this talk of fractal concepts, might sound a bit vague. Indeed, you might be thinking that I’ve sat in one too many strategy meetings myself. So here’s a data science specific example.

Imagine you are the billionaire owner of a quantitative hedge fund. Feels pretty sweet, right? Your hedge fund’s purpose might be to make macro-economic investments that play out over the long-term. To do this, it will, amongst other things, have to build better sources of macro-economic data than its competitors. Therefore you will create a data team to do this. There’s a purpose (macro investment), goal (build better data sources), and deployment of resources (create a data team) in this hedge fund’s strategy. Great! You’ve done your billionaire job and you can return to your private island / mountain fortress / whatever else you’re spending your money on.

Now suppose you run that data team. Your purpose is to build a better source of macro-economic data than anyone else, i.e. your purpose is the goal of the organisational level above you. Well you have to set yourself some goals to achieve your purpose. One will probably be to make available all the standard sources of macro-economic data from providers like Bloomberg. You can be 100% certain that people making trading decisions will want this.

However this only gets you to parity with other funds. Your purpose is to do better than them, remember? And hedge funds aren’t shy of shedding people who don’t fulfil their purpose. So you set yourself the additional goal of getting the people placing the bets (ahem, I mean “making investments”) to use alternative data sources that other funds don’t have. This could be information that you’ve extracted from news articles, or measured from satellite photos. To meet these goals, you hire a bunch of engineers to build the data feed from Bloomberg and a bunch of data scientists to work on the alternative data.

Now suppose you run the alternative data half of the data team. Your purpose is to provide alternative data sources that get used by people making trading decisions. So you talk to a quantitative analyst and discover that they’re interested in job sentiment data. Now you have a goal — extract job sentiment data — and you set a data scientist to extract this information from free-text articles in the Wall Street Journal. That lucky data scientist now has their purpose, so they set themselves a bunch of goals (get the data, plot the data, clean the data basically) and then work out what they have to do to complete them, i.e. use N.L.P. if they’re brave, or the Ctrl-C, Ctrl-V method if they’re wise.

In short, this is a well run hedge fund, whose strategy at the top has cascaded down to all levels of the organisation. In this world, strategy meetings are there for a reason. Everyone needs to know their purpose and how it fits in with the rest of the organisation. Then they can set themselves goals, and deploy their resources accordingly. This applies to everyone, even scientists!

I think one reason for the pain, and it’s a reason we have to face square-on, is that often there’s a lack of clarity about an organisation’s purpose at the very top. This lack of clarity then cascades down to all other levels.

For me, the nadir of this, was the sight of a CXO at a large nameless organisation who, when questioned on strategy, rolled his eyes and told the meeting that the company’s purpose was to “make more profit, obviously!” Now that’s roughly akin to an individual telling me that their life’s purpose is to draw another breath. Yes you have to breathe to live, but it’s not an end in itself. Equivalently, yes, a company has to make a profit to continue to exist, but that’s not why it exists.

Needless to say, that company was total chaos, as people tried to figure out what the hell they were supposed to be doing. Data strategy meetings were painful, as we tried to tease out what different parts of the organisation wanted, and more importantly, why. Put simply, if you think your data team’s purpose is to provide tools that make other people’s jobs easier, then it helps if those other people know what their jobs are.
So what can you do if you find yourself in this situation? Unfortunately I have no good news for you. You’re going to have to embrace the pain.

Firstly, you have to have a strategy, even if the rest of the organisation doesn’t. The hard part of this is, of course, to work out your team’s purpose. Once you know that, life’s easy — you can set your own goals and figure out how to use your own resources. A complicating factor is that you’re going to have to get a lock on your purpose for long enough that you can actually deliver something. To do this, you’re going to need allies! Or if you’re feeling a bit less Machiavellian, let’s call them internal customers. Either way, you’ll have to buddy up to other bits of the organisation and persuade them that their best interests lie with them getting their data science from you.
As an aside, I can see why data scientists hate this. In essence, it’s “Politics” and that’s something we don’t enjoy. Tough.

So at this stage you might feel that since you’re running around trying to get customers, you’re basically building an internal company of your own. Well I’d argue that you should embrace this feeling. Business schools even have a term for you: you’re an “Intrapreneur” [7]! How does it feel?

Anyway, if you accept that you’re building an internal start-up, it might be helpful to steal from those start-up value proposition templates [8]. One I like to use is: “We help X do Y by providing Z”.

In our case, we found our internal customers in the first step, so that’s our X. We know what they do, so we have our Y. And now it’s our job to figure out the Z. For example, “we help the customer retention team reduce churn by providing nudges at the appropriate point in the customer lifecycle.”

Congratulations! Providing that “Z” is your first purpose. Now figure out the goals: in our example, perhaps we decide to run experiments to find out which nudges measurably reduce churn? Maybe first build a model to predict who’ll churn? Then send an email? Push a notification in the app? Now you can hand off those goals to the people on your, and importantly, your customer’s, team.

There’s an obvious problem here. If you’re successful you’ll have lots of internal customers. So you’ll have lots of “Zs” that they want you to do. Your purpose is no longer clearly defined. It’s become a grab-bag of stuff that you happen to be doing.

Now I’d argue that this is the lesser evil — remember we’re operating in a chaotic environment here. When asked to justify your team’s existence, it’s infinitely better to respond with a whole long list of “we help X to do Y by providing Z” than it is to respond by trying to explain some sort of data science technology or technique that you’ve developed, for some reason.

However at some point, if you are lucky, you will see some recurring themes in the things you’re doing for your customers. Hopefully you can abstract these themes into an over-arching purpose. Let’s push the previous example a bit further. If you have a bunch of projects for marketing teams, but no-one else, perhaps your purpose is to provide tools that allow marketing to increase revenue? You can probably think of some goals that you’ll have to do to achieve this: improve the efficacy of campaigns by more accurate measurement, optimise customer outreach, help develop products for under-served markets. With a bit of luck some of these goals will align with the projects that you’re doing already. The ones that don’t then lay out a roadmap for what you should be doing next.

So in summary, if you’re in an organisation without a clear strategy, you have no choice but to define your own purpose, in collaboration with your colleagues in other departments. Then you can set your goals, and deploy your resources, as you see fit.
Without any guidance on strategy from above, you’ll have to build a strategy from opportunities that you go out and find.

Well much as I’d like this to be true — and who doesn’t love moaning about senior management — life is more complicated. I think there are two more factors that are playing out, and as data scientists, we have to be a bit self critical about these.

The first factor is that as you get more senior, you increasingly have to inspire people with a vision. Almost by definition, inspiring visions aren’t detailed and data-driven (the sort of things that we data scientists like), they’re abstract, high-level narratives (the sort of thing that the rest of the world likes).

To give a concrete example, consider a media company whose CEO states that their purpose is to give a voice to a historically under-served community. I can imagine a certain kind of data scientist dismissing that purpose. How can you measure an abstract concept like “voice”? That’s stupid, the CEO is an idiot.
I’d argue that here, the data scientist is in the wrong.

At this top-level you don’t really need to define “voice” for this to be a perfectly fine strategy. And if you’re from that under-served community you’ll probably be inspired by it, which is its most important function. Even if you’re not, you can immediately see what needs to be done. You’ll need to engage with that community. You’ll need to understand what they’re thinking. You’ll need to find out what media they consume, so you can produce the right content for them. In other words, understanding that you have to provide a “voice” is perfectly sufficient to get a series of “why / what / how” sub-strategies to cascade. It’s only further down the organisation that things have to start getting measured.
So in this case, its not the CEO that’s the idiot.

There’s another factor playing out though. A senior manager laying out a vision is describing a future state of the world. In other words, they’re saying the world is currently like this, it should be like that, and we have to do a whole bunch of stuff to get from here to there. Implicit in any discussions of the future is some sort of prediction of what the future is going to be.

And data scientists hate predictions! After all we’re the ones who know how hard they are! However as a senior manager, you have to make some sort of prediction about how the future is going to play out. You are steering a super tanker, and you know that any course corrections made now will take years to have an effect.

So who’s right? Well I think both sides are. Yes, it’s extremely difficult to make real predictions about the future, of the sort “Logan Rocks will win the 2.18 race at Doncaster”. However a senior manager has no choice but to attempt to imagine possible futures in creating their strategy.

Fortunately for all concerned there are a set of tools available that help make describing future worlds, if not scientific, at least a bit more rational. However, I think that they are sufficiently interesting that they deserve a post of their own and I’ve already gone on a little long this week! To hear more, you’ll have to return next Wednesday. Talk to you then.

[1] So it turns out that some people love JIRA, which came as a surprise. My final word is that if you look at a woodworking tool on Amazon and 90% of reviews say “I cut myself with it”, then either you can believe 90% of people are idiots who don’t know how to use a chisel, or alternatively, you might believe that just maybe there’s something wrong with the chisel. I’m in the latter camp.
[2] Everyone I’ve read on Strategy seems to reference Clausewitz’s “On War”, so here it is! Unfortunately for my rhetorical purposes, he seems not to have had a moustache.

[3] Basically I’ve taken the Ends / Ways / Means model and rejigged it to make the terminology consistent with the kind of design thinking we were talking about a few weeks ago. See Defining Military Strategy, by Arthur F Lykke, Jr., Military Review, Vol 77, №1.
[4] I get excited when I get a couple of thousand views. Simon Sinek’s talk “How great leaders inspire action” is currently running at 12 million or so. It’s great, watch it here.

[5] I’m not claiming anything new here. See Figure 1 of this paper, “Military Strategy Revisited, A Critique of the Lykke Formulation” by Lt. Col. Richard E. Berkebile. The last military reference, I promise — it’s just that I found that those guys had thought about this the most clearly!
[6] I’d always vaguely associated this line with the late, great Terry Pratchett, but it turns out I was completely wrong!
[7] I’m cheerfully simplifying this whole discussion. See here, and here for point and counterpoint, both from the Harvard Business Review.
[8] See, for example, 7 Proven Templates for Writing Value Propositions That Work, Tor Grønsund.
Your home for data science. A Medium publication sharing concepts, ideas and codes.
Before founding the http://efficientdatagroup.com, Dave was Head of Data Science at News UK. He’s managed data science teams in tech, media & finance.
